caption:
The photograph depicts a natural scene where the focal point is the inside view from within a hollowed, burnt tree trunk. The interior of the trunk is heavily charred and the surface showcases a rugged, deeply grooved black texture, which hints at the tree having survived a fire. From this vantage point, there is a view out towards a forest of tall, slender pine trees. These trees stand closely together, their trunks straight and seemingly unmarred, contrasting sharply with the burnt interior from which the image is captured.

The aperture formed by the hollowed trunk frames the forest scene in an irregular, organic shape, drawing the eye towards the light and the green of the pine trees outside. The forest background is well-lit, suggesting daylight conditions, in contrast to the dark, shadowed interior of the trunk. On the floor of the trunk, there are remnants of pine needles and small bits of debris, likely from the tree itself or deposited there by the wind.

This composition uses natural contrasts—between dark and light, inside and outside, damaged and intact—and offers a narrative of survival and natural resilience. The perspective is unique, giving an almost intimate look at the aftermath of forest fires, and the ongoing life just beyond.
title: Sequoias in mist.  Photographed through burned "tunnel tree" in the "burnt forest."
